title: Murder at Millbrook Manor
author: Original Sample Script
description: A silly dinner party mystery. Someone killed Gerald over the mushroom course. The suspects are all still at the table. Solve it before dessert.

characters.name: Lady Millbrook
characters.description: The imperious hostess with too many secrets
characters.costumeIdeas: A shawl or scarf draped dramatically, pearls if available. Look imperious at all times. Never panic, even when accused of murder.

characters.name: Colonel Biscuit
characters.costumeIdeas: A blazer with badges or pins. Military posture — chest out, chin up. Reference the Boer War as often as possible.

characters.name: Prudence
characters.description: The nervous young maid who knows everything
characters.costumeIdeas: An apron or dish towel over one arm. Stand near doorways. Look as though you've just overheard something you shouldn't have.

characters.name: Dr. Fennwick
characters.description: A pompous physician with dubious credentials
characters.costumeIdeas: A dark jacket. Speak very slowly and formally. Occasionally pause as though listening to an internal ringing sound.

characters.name: Vera
characters.costumeIdeas: Something elegant but slightly suspicious. Cross your arms a lot. You have clearly been planning this confrontation for weeks.

beats.text: The dining room of Millbrook Manor. A half-eaten dinner sits on the table. The lights flicker.
I must say, the soufflé was a triumph.
Even if poor Gerald is no longer with us to appreciate it.
Dreadful business. Absolutely dreadful.
I've seen men go down in the Khyber Pass, but never mid-soup course.
Auntie, shouldn't we call the police?
And ruin dessert? Absolutely not.
As a medical man, I can confirm that Gerald is, in fact, deceased.
I base this on the fact that he has not moved in forty minutes.
Begging your pardon, but I did see something peculiar before dinner.
Prudence! Speak up!
Someone was in the pantry, ma'am. Fiddling with the mushroom tray.
Everyone looks slowly at Lady Millbrook.
I beg your pardon. I was simply arranging them artistically.
I didn't eat the mushrooms. Suspicious of fungi since the Boer War.
I ate the mushrooms. I feel perfectly fine.
Although I do have a slight ringing in my ears. Probably unrelated.
Uncle Gerald ate every last one. He said they were delicious.
And then he said 'I feel rather odd' and keeled over.
His last words were actually 'more gravy, please.'
And then the odd feeling comment. I have them in the correct order.
Someone in this room is a murderer!
Dramatic pause. The candles flicker.
Colonel, please. We don't use that word at the dinner table.
What word do you prefer? The ringing is getting louder.
Auntie, you stand to inherit everything if Gerald is gone.
What an unpleasant thing to bring up at the table.
We haven't even had the cheese course.
Madam, I must insist we get to the bottom of this.
There is no bottom, sir. I cleaned under the table this morning.
That's not what he meant, Prudence.
I should examine the body more carefully.
Dr. Fennwick stands, sways slightly, and sits back down.
In a moment. I need to collect myself first.
Well. Does anyone want more wine while we sort this out?
